candidates.title: [-> #739] Special handling for unsubscribe calls.
candidates.body:
Also point at Tokio 1.16 since we use a method added then.

This avoids acquiring a permit for unsubscribe calls, so that they always make it past the subscription limit.

(I wonder whether they should also avoid any resource claiming, too?)

This is to be merged into #739 if we're happy with the approach! 

Todo: 
- [ ] Add a test to check that unsubscribe methods make it past the limit.
- [ ] Check/fix proc macro stuff?

candidates.title: fix(rpc module): fail subscription calls with bad params
candidates.body:
To summarize, with this PR:
- We can reject a pending subscription with a `{ jsonrpc: "2.0", error: {...}, "id":<ID> }` style error of our choice using `pending.reject(error)`.
- We can end a subscription at any time with `{ jsonrpsee: "2.0", method: "subscribe_foo", params: { subscription: "123abc", error: { ... } } }` style error using `sink.close(error)`.
- Subscriptions that are dropped are now not silently closed with an error anymore (for compatibility reasons, incase subscriptions want to signal that they got closed by: "completed successfully" or "error" they must either call `close` on SubscriptionSink explictly). In other words, we enforce no opinion on what happens when a subscription is closed, and leave it up to the subscription itself to decide whether to emit an "error" or communicate closure via some other "ordinary notification".
- The clients have been changed to require the new error format for closing subscriptions `{ jsonrpsee: "2.0", method: "subscribe_foo", params: { subscription: "123abc", error: { ... } } }`
- `Subscription::next` in the client no longer parses `SubscriptionClosed` instead just returns `None` when a closed message is received.

Tested it on: https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/compare/dp-jsonrpsee-integration-2...na-jsonrpsee-comp-bad-params?expand=1

Improve current benchmarks to run up 1024 concurrent connections,

websocket 10 calls are sent per connections
http 1 call per connection (doesn't make sense make several calls using the http client)

candidates.title: Replace async-channel
candidates.body:
Replace `async-channel` with `tokio::sync::Notify` to use a dependency less and (possibly?) be a bit faster by using a lighter primitive (maybe?). The problem the `async-channel` is solving is: how does the `SubscriptionSink` know about rude subscribers that leaves without calling `unsubscribe_*`? Using a full-on channel for this might be overkill and this is an attempt at fixing that.

Fixes https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/issues/691

candidates.title: fix(rpc module): unsubscribe according ethereum pubsub spec
candidates.body: As we already have adopted the [ethereum pubsub spec](https://geth.ethereum.org/docs/rpc/pubsub) for subscriptions let's stick to it completely.

candidates.title: refactor(ws server): impl `IdProvider` for Box<T>
candidates.body:
Implement `IdProvider` for `Box<T>` to support `Box<dyn IdProvider>`, in addition I also added `std::fmt::Debug` to the IdProvider.

//cc @maciejhirsz 
I had a look how difficult it would be to make this purely static dispatch because currently we pass `dyn IdProvider` to the RpcModule if the call is a subscription,

Then we would have to add a type param on `Methods`, `RpcModule` and related types and the only user-facing would be the the `RpcModule` which is a bit annoying but it would kill the extra indirection's. The benefit of this is that we could get rid of the `Arc<dyn IdProvider>` to `I: IdProvider` and require `Clone` on IdProvider.

parking_lot 0.12.0, parking_lot_core 0.9.0, lock_api 0.4.6 (2022-01-28)

  • The MSRV is bumped to 1.49.0.
  • Disabled eventual fairness on wasm32-unknown-unknown. (#302)
  • Added a rwlock method to report if lock is held exclusively. (#303)
  • Use new asm! macro. (#304)
  • Use windows-rs instead of winapi for faster builds. (#311)
  • Moved hardware lock elision support to a separate Cargo feature. (#313)
  • Removed used of deprecated spin_loop_hint. (#314)

  • Fixed incorrect memory orderings on RwLock and WordLock. (#294, #292)
  • Added Arc-based lock guards. (#291)
  • Added workaround for TSan's lack of support for fence. (#292)

lock_api 0.4.4 (2021-05-01)

  • Update for latest nightly. (#281)

lock_api 0.4.3 (2021-04-03)

  • Added [Raw]ReentrantMutex::is_owned. (#280)

parking_lot_core 0.8.3 (2021-02-12)

parking_lot_core 0.8.2 (2020-12-21)

parking_lot_core 0.8.1 (2020-12-04)

  • Fixed build on wasm32-unknown-unknown. (#265)
  • Relaxed dependency on smallvec. (#266)

parking_lot 0.11.1, lock_api 0.4.2 (2020-11-18)

  • Fix incorrect memory ordering in RwLock. (#260)

lock_api 0.4.1 (2020-07-06)

candidates.title: Prep for releasing v0.8.0
candidates.body: Release prep for v0.8.0﻿

candidates.title: Add a method to RpcModule that transforms the module into a `RpcModule<()>`, i.e. removes the context.
candidates.body: Closes #558﻿

candidates.title: fix(jsonrpsee): feature `macros` include client types
candidates.body: Closing https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/issues/649

candidates.title: feat: WASM client via web-sys transport
candidates.body:
This PR adds `web-sys` transport to the jsonrpsee client in the browser (via WebSocket), it actually uses "std" currently but I'm not sure whether this will be an issue or not for users.

I added another feature flag `async-wasm-client` to `core` to use a client to that spawns a background task using `wasm_bindgen_futures::spawn_local` instead of `tokio` similar to how `async-client` works. We can probably bikeshed on the naming there.

Another option is to go by `target.'cfg(target_arch = wasm32 )' instead to reduce the number of complicated feature flags to understand in this repo...

Closing #606

candidates.title: fix(ws client): expose tls feature.
candidates.body: The TLS feature was missing which this fixes and enables it by default.

candidates.title: feat(rpc module): `stream API` for SubscriptionSink
candidates.body:
Fixes https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/issues/627

This PR introduces a new API for the `SubscriptionSink` to add a stream to send items over the subscription when "new items" get produced, if the connection gets closed it will terminate the task because it has additional channel linked to actual connection.

candidates.title: fix(http server): handle post and option HTTP requests properly.
candidates.body: Partly fixes https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/issues/628

candidates.title: chore: migrate to rust 2021
candidates.body: Implies MSRV 1.56.x

candidates.title: fix(jsonrpsee wrapper): make ws tls configurable
Upgrade `tracing-subscriber`
candidates.body: Upgrade the crate and add the required feature.﻿

candidates.title: feat: server configurable subscriptionID
candidates.body: Closing #599

candidates.title: Remove usage of the `palaver` crate in an example
benches: make jsonrpc crates optional
candidates.body: Make the dependency tree smaller with the default bench dependencies.

candidates.title: types: make subscription ID String Cow.
clients: use `FxHashMap` instead `FnvHashMap`
candidates.body: `FxHashMap` is already used in the `utils crate` then let's use it in the clients too because it's faster and to reduce the dependencies a bit.

candidates.title: Crate restructuring
candidates.body:
I need to start making smaller PRs. This one is pretty straight forward, removed the v2 module and moved things around to hopefully sensible locations.

Rationale: We added the `v2` module when doing some internal refactoring that ultimately lead to different versions of types with similar names (`Request` most notably), but have since unified the apis to use same types, and with the "v1" absent there is no need for the module to exist.

Edit: [see comment](https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpsee/pull/590#issuecomment-993425547) for ongoing changes.

candidates.title: An example of adding multiple middlewares.
extract async client abstraction.
candidates.body:
Let's have a round of reviews for this too, it extracts the `shareable` parts of the `ws client` to an `async client abstration`. 
I have called it `core-client` and it's not used by `HTTP` because it can't be extracted to a `sending` and `receiving` end.
That's we have two different transport traits for a `sender` and `receiver` such that they can be used in different tasks.

We can bikeshed on the naming....

Remaining is to expose the client transports from the wrapper crate `jsonrpsee`

I have tested it in [`subxt here`](https://github.com/paritytech/subxt/pull/341)

The benefit that it would be easy to add other transports such as `IPC`, `web-sys` and so on...

candidates.title: Add a setter for middleware
candidates.body:
…and an example. 

Came about as way to review #576

candidates.title: Middleware for metrics
candidates.body:
Still a bunch of loose ends: 

+ [x] Add a method to set the metrics on the server builder.
+ [x] HTTP server side.
+ [x] TODO doc comments.
+ [x] Test / examples.

Other than that it should be functional and is backwards compatible. I needed to add an extra boxed future in async method call pipeline that I may be able to remove down the line (depending on how much I want to mess with the `FutureDriver`).
